conclusion: To solve this problem, we need to analyze the forces acting on both hemispheres and use the given conditions to find the dynamic friction coefficient between hemisphere A and the left wall.
Between the vertical walls are hemispheres A and B with masses m and 2m respectively.
The line between the two ball centers and the horizontal direction into A is at a 30° angle.
The maximum static friction is equal to the sliding friction force.
Hemisphere A has a weight \( W_A = m \cdot g \), a normal force from the wall \( N_A \), and a frictional force \( f_A \) acting horizontally to the right.
Hemisphere B has a weight \( W_B = 2m \cdot g \), a normal force from the wall \( N_B \), and a frictional force \( f_B \) acting horizontally to the right.

premise: Since the two hemispheres are in equilibrium and do not slide, the frictional forces must balance the components of the normal forces that would cause them to move.
The angle between the line connecting the centers of the two hemispheres and the horizontal is 30°.
conclusion: The line connecting the centers forms a 30° angle with the horizontal.

premise: The horizontal component of the normal force \( N_A \) is \( N_A \cos(30^\circ) \).
conclusion: The horizontal component of \( N_A \) is \( N_A \cos(30^\circ) \).

premise: The vertical component of the normal force \( N_A \) is \( N_A \sin(30^\circ) \).
conclusion: The vertical component of \( N_A \) is \( N_A \sin(30^\circ) \).

premise: The frictional force \( f_A \) acts horizontally to the right and balances the horizontal component of the weight of hemisphere B.
The normal force \( N_B \) acts vertically upward and balances the weight of hemisphere B.
The frictional force \( f_B \) acts horizontally to the right and balances the horizontal component of the weight of hemisphere A.
conclusion: The frictional force \( f_B = N_B \cos(30^\circ) = 2mg \cos(30^\circ) = 2mg \cdot \frac{\sqrt{3}}{2} = mg\sqrt{3} \).
